ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Graph theory, number theory, proofs by induction. Really good mathematical knowledge for computer science. Many times the lessons tied into what I was learning in CS223 as well.
How to solve proofs

For anyone with a competitive and/or rigorous math background, you will know >50% of the material already.  The remaining material is fairly easy; the only new topics for me personally were graph theory and formal logic proofs.
I learned A TON of logic and discreet math.

This course teaches you how to think about seemingly obvious problems. We had to prove things which we are used to see as common sense, but now have a deep understanding of. We also learned proofing techniques, which is very helpful when thinking about a Computer Science problem, as this course teaches you the logic fundamentals and how to think of things from the perspective of a mathematician or a logic-person, which closely resembles the functioning of a computer.
I gained a surface-level overview of several topics in discrete math, including logic, modular arithmetic, graph theory, and counting.

A introduction to to logic, sets and functions, induction, number theory, relations, and graph theory. The material covered overlapped many of my intro EE or CS classes so it was nice to get another refresher on the topics. Probably one of more doable math classes at Yale.
The math required for computer science and critical thinking skills.
I greatly developed my understanding of various discrete math topics and improved my connections between mathematics and computer science.
A good understanding of set theory and graph theory. Strong comprehension of logic and other fundamentals useful for computer science.
Mathematica reasoning and a look into the math that computers use

This course felt like a survey of important math concepts needed for computer science. It was a great introduction to proof-writing. I also learned a lot about number theory and a bit about combinatorics and graph theory.
Some basic topics like number theory, predicate and propositional logic, graph theory, proofs, combinatorics.
a greater understanding of the various math concepts that are related to CS (propositional logic, number and graph theory, inductive proofs)
Mathskills
I learned various math concepts and ideas behind different computer science topics such as recursion, algorithms, time complexity (big O notation), and more.
applicable math tools for Computer Science
I have a cursory overview of discrete mathematics and thinking about mathematical problems that may appear in CS
Reading proofs.
I developed knowledge in computational logic and areas like graph theory and induction.
Learned to construct mathematical proofs to solve problems in propositional logic, graphs, number theory, combinatorics, and much more.
I developed a good knowledge of discrete mathematics and proof-based math. I learned about trees, Euclidean's algorithm, how to write proofs, etc.
basics of number theory, combinatorics, graph theory, predicate logic, proofs, induction
I learned a lot about logic and the methods of proving things.
I developed a better understanding of lots of different discrete math concepts, and to an extent also how they apply in CS (e.g. RSA encryption). Also lots of proof examples
Basic proof writing and fundamental mathematical ideas.
It improved my understanding of discreet math, a topic I had superficial knowledge about.
Proof based thinking and logic.
Among other skills, writing/thinking through proofs, especially informal proofs.
Discrete mathematics and tools for computer science
Learned about some essential math for cs majors.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class is structured really well and covers a wide-range of topics within Discrete Mathematics

I loved this course, although some of the content was not clearly applicable to computer science. I'm not sure if the applications will become clear in later classes, but putting more of the material in context, even if it's only "you might use this in xyz class or in xyz situation," would be appreciated.

The course was very enjoyable; I had a lot of fun taking it. One particular weakness was office hours being held at the most inconvenient times. The problem sets were typically due on Tuesdays, and there were a lot of office hours Wednesday through Friday, which is when I would focus on other courses, and not many office hours on the days leading up to the submission deadline. I think office hours should be made closer to the deadline, or at least, split evenly so as to allow students to use help when needed. Most students don't work on a problem set 2 immediately after they submit problem set 1.

The course was taught well, and the problem sets and exams were very reasonable. I'd say the main weakness of the course is that it doesn't go in depth into any topics, instead opting for maximal breadth. I'm not sure exactly what of this information is necessary for a CS major, but I can't see how most of the content of the course would be applicable, as most of the material was either very intuitive or covering topics not directly relevant to coding.

Professor Bridy always made sure to give enough time to prepare for tests and to complete psets. The ULA's and TA's grading of homework was always very thorough and they would leave a lot of comments. Same with the homework and homewoek solutions always being posted on a timely manner. 

The course material was straightforward but felt very loosely structured off the textbook. As expected with introductory courses, I felt that there was a lot that we didn't get to cover. I hope this will not make future classes more difficult.
Course was very good.

I think the course could be related more to computer science, especially since it is part of the department, and covered less material than I had hoped it would. At the same time, professor Bridy did a great job of pacing the course, so I am not sure how more material could have been covered. Additionally, there was a good availability of teaching fellows and the consistent inclusion of practice problems during class made the material much more understandable compared to a lecture where material is just presented and students are expected to identify how to use the material in the problem sets.
This class is incredibly organized and overall great. The only weakness is the lack of advanced warning about the date of exams.
Great teacher and week my week workload. Only weakness would be there arent many resources outside of the class for reading that are available other than text book

Strengths: manageable and applicable psets, Bridy is a very patient instructor and receptive to students' questions, exams are fair, lecture notes are organized Weakness: distribution of materials -- I wish there was more of a focus on linear algebra and run-time instead of number theory (but this semester did present some challenges that decreased the time we could spend on certain topics), could be a bit more challenging
Was taught in a way that made the material easier to understand. I think the main weakness is that we dont really cover a lot of material for the class to be too useful.
Nicely structured. Great teaching.
I appreciated the examples that we worked through in class, but overall I thought that the lectures could have been more engaging.

Strengths: Professor Bridy was a great instructor for this class, and made the concepts really clear. If you understood the psets well, you were able to understand the material in the course (and they corresponded well to each other). TAs at office hours were also always helpful with answering questions.
Great. professor, interesting and fun content
Honestly, it was a really good course. Nothing much that I would change.
Well organized, wished there was more of a computer science focus.
I thought all the material was interesting and well-taught. Honestly, the class moved a bit slow.
The TAs were helpful and the assignments were clear. Help was easily available.
I personally really liked Prof Bridy's teaching style and he explained things well, psets and exams were all reasonable and you're given practice exams that help prepare you for them
Strengths: Professor Bridy is a great and understanding professor! There are office hours available for extra help. Weaknesses: some of the assignments took a great amount of time to be graded.

Great teaching if you take it with Bridy. A lot of topics we just skim the surface over so you won't get a really deep understanding of any particular topic. Still a great class for those wanting to explore.
instructor was clear and always available to help; made content accessible

Great class all around.

The only thing is sometimes the TAs could have provided more explanation on psets when grading.
I do wish that there could have been a little time spent explaining common mistakes that people make when constructing a proof. It was just hard to know when your line of reasoning was faulty or not.

Prof Bridy is a really kind and understanding professor. He teaches with lots of examples, and combines both writing out examples with PowerPoint proofs  super effective imo. I wasnt a fan of the grading scheme though, as making just a few small mistakes end up bringing you below the average for 24-hr open book exams
Strength: Good pace and creates a solid fundamental platform.
The class is well taught and Prof. Bridy is engaging as well as very understanding.
The structure of the course was very fleshed out and the support from the peer tutors was extremely helpful and accessible.
Strength: It's a pretty chill class and covers some interesting topics.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual office hours were helpful
Keep office hours online and keep recording lectures for later review. Everything else was amazing.

The professor was very accessible, and also very understanding. Out of all my teachers, he was the one to care most for his students, cancelling homeworks occasionally and allowing us students to feel less pressure in these times. He would also dedicate many lectures to answering questions, which was really nice. I also liked the stress-free exams that we had, since we could pace ourselves and work on them throughout the day, instead of feeling pressured and watched. This also allowed for me to think deeply about the problems and analyze them carefully, which let me appreciate the material and not just try and get it done with.

The format of the course was great- recorded lectures with captions that could be speeded up or slowed down as necessary. The open-note 24-hour exams were also very convenient, and made a lot of sense since the material involved more problem solving than memorization.
The organization of the course was very cognizant of the break days and the necessary "break" time so I never felt extremely stressed about the deadlines.
All were good.

The recorded lectures made the class a lot more manageable by affording the option for remote learning when possible. Additionally, Prof. Bridy's responsiveness to questions during live class still made the live lecture useful and helpful.
The lectures were recorded which was very helpful. There were also really helpful psets and practice problems.
All good. Zoom is annoying but it was smooth in this class
Succeeded: use of screensharing slides and whiteboard To Be Improved: encourage more students to share answers using chat functionality?
Lectures were uploaded to canvas. There were a lot of office hours. Class policies were particularly lenient.
Recorded lectures allowed us to revisit any topics we got lost on during class.
The whiteboard feature used in class was very helpful, but I would have liked more of that and less of the powerpoint presentation.
TA help

I think more interactive classes could have been used because watching someone talk at you behind a screen everyday felt redundant and honestly left no opportunity to learn because if I didn't understand enough to ask a questions, I would get left behind.
I thought the homework assignments and virtual lectures all succeeded.
I liked that lectures were recorded because it allows you to look back on the professor's explanations for extra help.
Everything about this course was great and well adjusted to the pandemic. Professor Bridy recorded lectures while also providing students with the chance to attend office hours virtually.

Virtual engagement in lectures was minimal, but prof really tried his best to engage students by asking questions. Prof was available for office hours regularly, and also gave us plenty of practice exams & a 24-hr open book exam. I think he adapted super well
Lectures were very clear!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course. Office hours and often essential for answering the psets (definitely a time saver)
Yes if you need it for a CS requirement

I recommend this class for people who had a very standard high school math education and who have not seen more advanced/varied topics such as modular arithmetic, induction, probability, formal logic, etc.
Yes -- p-sets were short and pretty straightforward (based on class examples). Having only two exams was also a plus.
Yes. I loved this course's approach to logic and numbers. It was so interesting!

Yes! If you would like to learn LaTex, enjoy thinking deeply about abstract things, or just like writing proofs that seem complicated and make you look smart, you should take the class. It is definitely enjoyable and has a lot of the fun things from Math, without the boring things from Math.

I'd recommend it if you need this for a CS major or to take an upper-level CS class but are not too invested in the math itself. If you want a more thorough, proof-based understanding of discrete math the course through the math department is a better option (and also fulfills the CS requirement).
Yes. The material covered fundamental and reoccurring concepts in CS and many other STEM fields.
If they were interested in math or computer science.

Yes. Professor Bridy does a great job of teaching, and the material is interesting and informative. Additionally, the workload is manageable as long as the lectures are watched with attention, especially due to the practice problems done in class.
Yes. This is by far the best math class I have taken thus far in my Yale career. It is well explained and organized.
Yes. It is taught well and is never overwhelming. Plenty of resources fir help with office hours and such

I would recommend this to CS majors who have yet to learn about combinatorics and graph theory, along with those who are still new to proof-writing. Students with a bit of background knowledge might consider MATH 244 instead. The course felt manageable with 223, and everything was well-organized.
If you want to be a comp sci major, this class is required. Its a pretty good class, its not too stressful so dont be afraid of taking too many comp sci classes in a semester.
Yes! Solid foundation of different math concepts that are related to CS.
Yes, if it's for the major
Yes, it was a fun class if you like math. I would recommend it if students need an easier math credit.
If youre interested in easier discrete math or need a QR than this isnt bad.
I enjoyed the course, but if it had not been a pre-requisite for the computer science major, I would not have taken it.
If you need it for the major then you have to take it. I would definitely recommend it because it's linear algebra and discrete math taught in a simpler way.
CPSC majors are required to take this course or equivalent, but I would recommend it to anyone who would like a brief but engaging overview of discrete math, number theory, and combinatorics.
Yes, required for the CS major but a nice change from other core classes in the major since it's not coding, pretty doable with a 5-course workload
Yes, if interested in discrete mathematics and writing proofs. Also, it is a cs requirement.
Yes! Bridy is great
I would recommend this course. It does a good intro to discrete math and assumes no prior knowledge.

Only for the major. Its a pretty good class and you definitely learn quite a bit (its more math than CS) but I dont quite see the point in taking it unless youre planning on using this type of discrete math in CS
Yes! Great course for Somputer Science majors that is not too stressful yet interesting and new.

Yes, the class covers a lot of material but the professor makes it very easy to understand in digestible portions. The workload is also just right. It is not as tedious as other math classes where the questions are often repetitive.
Yes; I felt that the course material was interesting, and that through practice I learned a lot in terms of how to apply statements taken as fact in logical reasoning and proofs.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Recorded live virtual lectures.
We had a live virtual lecture that was recorded. I mainly watched the recorded lecture afterwards.
None.
Like many spring classes, the live virtual lectures were recorded. Professor Bridy used a different platform from the Canvas Media Library, which had access to both the video transcript and chat.
N/A
Frequent office hours.
Live and recorded. Both availabke
N/A
Live lectures werent mandatory. The lectures were recorded and uploaded to canvas.
There were live lectures twice a week, but they were also recorded.
N/A
Office hours
n/a
Live virtual lecture with each lecture being recorded for student use.
ULA help sessions
Live virtual lecture but lectures were also recorded.
Live virtual lectures that are also recorded to allow for asynchronous attendance.
